value.0: Hello <FirstName>, what can I do for you?

Hi <FirstName>! Aren't you excited? It's our final day as lowly subjects of the Empire and our first as true citizens! Or at least it will be as soon as we can get through this ceremony. Is there anyway I can help with the Judgement?

I can't imagine not having them! They traveled for three days from Lac Brier so they could be here, even with the floods. They're exhausted and haven't even unpacked the mules but they wouldn't have missed the ceremony for all the world.
You're a lucky girl, Alia. Your parents really love you, especially your mother! She seems nearly ecstatic about you gaining citizenship.
Mom was pregnant with me when graduated from this Academy and wasn't able to attend the final ceremony so in some ways this one is for the both of us.

It's good to see them again, though. It's been so long since I last went home. <StartAction>[Alia glances at her mother's smiling, tear-stained face and gives a little wave.]</Start> Your father will arrive soon, <FirstName>. I know he will...

Time at the Academy moves quickly for you, doesn't it... As for me, I love you all dearly but I can't help to get back to the woods. The druid council said they'd name me as a true druid on my return.
A true druid and a true citizen of the Empire! Won't it be wonderful, <FirstName>?
Okay, what would you like to know?

Home is home and family is family. My parents will stay here long enough to recover from the journey then we'll leave for the woods. I don't know if I'll ever even come back to the city... It's a long journey, <FirstName>...

You can take the druid out of the wood but you can't take the wood out of the druid, isn't that what they say? <StartAction>[Janthos gives Alia a friendly punch on the shoulder.]</Start> We'll miss you, Alia, but we won't keep you.
And I will miss both of you. You've both been the most wonderful friends a girl could dream of. Come on, <FirstName>. Stop stalling and let's be done with this Judgement.

Rakha protects the Empire. Even before there was an Empire, he protected the people of the cities and the trees of the forest. He's done so much for all of us who follow his teachings. With all he's done for the forest, I think he may be a brother druid.

A druid? That's a joke, right? Rakha has the heart of an inventor. He's designed the entire Empire to perfection: every citizen has a role, every city its defenses. He doesn't have time to worry about the trees, Alia. He has people like you to do that.
Oh, and you've met Emperor Rahka, have you? No, I didn't think so! Anyway, I was helping <FirstName>, so there...

Oh, I guess great <Lord/lLady> <FirstName>, the pompous noble, has the Emperor over for tea on a daily basis! <StartAction>[Alia offers a wicked grin that the seems to save especially for you.]</Start>
I'm sure the mighty and powerful High <Lord/Lady> <FullName>, <CUSTOM6001> of the great Magistrate, has the Emperor shining <his/her> shoes each morning on the way to class!
All right, all right. Enough of this jest. <StartAction>[Alia winks at you.]</Start> Do you have any other questions, your <lord/lady>ship?

I guess it doesn't, really. <StartAction>[Alia offers you a puzzled frown.]</Start> Whatever the Emperor is, he seems to hold the peace and protection of his citizens in high regard and we all have that to be thankful for at the very least.

A what!? <He/She>'s even crazier than you are, Janthos. <StartAction>[Alia shakes her head, a confused expression on her face.]</Start> In any case, Rakha is the one who brings us hope in dark times like these.

Well whatever Rakha is, he protects the cities *and* the forests. He's a hero to be respected, and he saved us all from dread King Khagrim. He's a good leader in these times of peril and that's what matters.
That much we can agree upon! <StartAction>[Janthos grins widely, the original dispute already long forgotten.]</Start> Now what were you asking Alia again?

I don't know. I was staying with my family in the forest at the time and we really don't pay much attention to what happens here in the city... With the exception of the Academy, of course... I'm not sure what to tell you, <FirstName>.

You don't remember the "Black Butcher?" The heralds were calling out the news throughout half the Empire two years ago! Foolish druids. If a bird falls sick in the forest, you all know of it but if a hundred city-folk are killed you never hear a thing!

Two years? His spirit has been trapped here for that long? It's not natural! He should have been sent to the afterlife! It's up to the Spirit Cycle to cleanse sins from the dead, no matter what their crime.

Please, <FirstName>, the spirit of any living thing should be allowed to pass on when it dies. The Spirit Cycle spirit is a natural thing, as plain as breathing. We have no right to interfere in it, not even as citizens of the Empire.
Blah blah blah. Yakir is a heinous criminal, an abomination to your precious nature, not a part of it. If Rahka holds him to this plane, it's for good reason!

<He/She> asked me about the Spirit Cycle, Janthos, so kindly keep your comments to yourself. You see, <FirstName>, we all pass through the cycle of life, death, and rebirth. It's a natural process and helps maintain balance in the world.

People are born. In life, they make their choices, sowing the seeds of imbalance in the world. In death, the balance is restored through the blessings and punishments of Heaven and Hell so they can be reborn, pure and new, into the world.
To trap him here, away from Heaven or Hell, is to preserve that imbalance. If he is as evil as Janthos claims, then you have made the world more evil by keeping him here. Don't you see, Janthos?

Hogwash! He made his bed and he should lie in it, Alia. If he really is going to be reborn like you claim, he'll just make the same choices all over again and how many other people will lose their families over it? Don't let it happen, <FirstName>... I beg you...
W-What did you call me!? You arrogant, highborn scum! Nobles like you know nothing of the people's suffering! You're nothing but the spoiled seed of your greater father!
<StartAction>[Alia stares slack-jawed at the both of you.]</Start> Please, stop this bickering! Janthos, I'd have thought your rage would be spent by now!

And <FirstName>, your rudeness falls far below your rank! If you're going to be a dignitary like your father, you should try to be a little more diplomatic. I wouldn't have believed you capable of tormenting poor Janthos like that.

<StartAction>[Alia's face brightens with rage.]</Start> Why you filthy weasel! Actually, even a weasel has more honor than the likes of you! Well I won't let a tomfool noble<man/woman> like you ruin the day I gain my citizenship...
No wonder the Magistrate never came. Even your own father is too embarrassed to claim you as his own! Why, you should be-- <StartAction>[Janthos places a concerned hand on Alia's shoulder.]</Start>
Uh... I didn't mean for it to come to this, <FirstName>. This is our citizenship day and, well... we're all friends, right? Make what Judgement you must and let's move on, okay?
Yes, I... I let my temper get away with me. You are right about that much, Janthos. Now if the young <Lord/Lady> <LastName> has any more questions of me, <he/she> may ask...
Then perhaps you should develop some! Both of you are in the wrong here. I doubt you'll apologize to me or anyone but I will not let you ruin the day of my citizenship.

<StartAction>[Janthos grows pale as Alia turns her back on the both of you.]</Start> Wait! I apologize! I do... My outburst was uncalled for, and my rage... misdirected. I take responsibility for my actions.
Well... Thank you, Janthos. I would not have excepted a gnome to be the bigger person in this argument... Come, we have a Judgement to perform, <FirstName>. Do you have any more questions for me?
I apologize, too. It's not you I was angry at, <FirstName>, but allow me to take responsibility for my actions all the same. They were inappropriate.
It's all right. I take responsibility for my rant and the argument that followed. My outburst was uncalled for too, <FirstName>.
Now isn't it better when things fall back into balance? Now, back to the task at hand: Is there anything more I can help you with, <FirstName>?

<StartAction>[Janthos glares at you briefly but his gaze soon softens.]</Start> You know I lost my parents to brigands. I didn't mean to lash out like that but you must learn to be more sensitive to other people's feelings, mine included.
But I do ask that you let Rakha hold Yakir here where he can do no more damage. For the families still mourning their losses, if nothing else.
Well, let's agree to disagree, then. We've both come to our decisions honestly and you with more loss than I.
Oh, I'm so sorry, Janthos! This must remind you terribly of your loss. I can get so caught up in things and I... I wasn't thinking.
No, it's my fault. I can't mourn forever, can I? It's not you that I'm mad at. It never is... Please, excuse me.
Oh I'm sorry, Janthos. I know the memories this must be dredging up for you. I thought you had finally put your anger over what happened to your parents to rest.

I apologize. Please forgive my outburst, both of you. I have strong opinions on this matter but it's not my place to force them onto either of you, especially when you've been such good friends to me. Please, let's get on with the Judgement.
It's so clear but on the other hand it's so complicated. I mean, Emperor Rakha has my trust and respect and I know he only does what is right... but then why would he even allow us a choice?
If I'm to Judge by my conscience, then I think his spirit should be set free and allowed to travel to Heaven or Hell in accordance with the natural Spirit Cycle.
Are you okay? I didn't realize you felt so strongly about the Judgement... Thank you for freeing the spirit, at least. I just wish you were doing it for different reasons, that's all.
There are many means to an end but some paths in life are more dangerous than others. Be objective, that's all I ask...

Thank you, <FirstName>. Yakir's spirit won't go unpunished for his crimes in this life and the spirit cycle will cleanse him and give him another chance in the next. I know how hard a decision it was to make.

W-Wow! I've never heard such an eloquent statement, <FirstName>! Like it or not, your father's highborn blood runs thick in your veins... It's a good thing, <Lord/Lady> <LastName> and something to be proud of!
It looks like you've made your decision, <FirstName>. You really should have released the spirit to the underworld, but I believe your intentions were good.

That may be true. Oh, don't look at me like that! I know I am an idealist and I know that I've never lost anyone close to me, not like you and Janthos... But, even so, you should'nt judge others unless you're able to be objective about it.
Excuse me.
Glad to have your parents here?
I wish I'd had more time to get to know you.
Let's talk about something else.
Why can't you stay here in the city?
What do you think of Emperor Rakha?
All you filthy peasants claiming Rakha as your own...
Why does it matter what Rakha is?
What if Rakha's a druidic engineer?
I'm pretty sure Rakha's a <class>, like me.
What do you know of Yakir?
What do you mean by "Spirit Cycle"?
Enough whining, fool.
I will not apologize for my actions, peasant.
Hmpf! Diplomacy is a skill I will not learn.
Sorry about that, Janthos.
I apologize, my behavior was uncalled for.
Have we struck a nerve, Janthos?
What are you talking about?
Are you all right, Janthos?
What Judgement would you cast, Alia?
I refuse to accept your foolish notions.
Natural law before mortal law, Alia...
You've never lost someone close to you, Alia.
